qas.question: What strongly altered the power balances and perceptions of origin of power in the Mediterranean region?
What emphasized an inexorable link between science and religion?
Who challenged the early Islamic philosophy's views?
What type of views did the "rationalist" Mutaziite philosophers hold?
What help to balance the power in the Mediterranean region?
What early philosophy emphasize a separation between science and religion?
What philosophers placed revelation above reason?
Who were the first theologies of Islam?
Who said the Koran must be subordinate to reason?
What focused on a link between reason and freedom of action?
The rise of what was based on modern scholars views and science?
What group challenged the Hellenic view of Islam?
What must reason be subordinate to according to Mutazilite philosophers?
What process did speculative theologians use to find truth?

context: <a0_0><b4_0><b10_0>The rise of Islam<b10_0/><b4_0/><a0_0/>, based on both the Qur'an and Muhammad strongly altered the power balances and perceptions of origin of power in the Mediterranean region. <a1_0><b5_0><b9_0>Early Islamic philosophy<b9_0/><b5_0/><a1_0/> emphasized an inexorable link between science and religion, and the process of <b13_0>ijtihad<b13_0/> to find truth—in effect all philosophy was "political" as it had real implications for governance. This view was challenged by <a2_0><b11_0>the "rationalist" <b6_0><b7_0>Mutazilite philosophers<b11_0/><b7_0/><b6_0/><a2_0/>, who held a more <a3_0>Hellenic view<a3_0/>, reason above revelation, and as such are known to modern scholars as the first speculative theologians of Islam; they were supported by a secular aristocracy who sought freedom of action independent of the Caliphate. By the late ancient period, however, the "traditionalist" Asharite view of Islam had in general triumphed. According to the <b8_0>Asharites<b8_0/>, reason must be subordinate to <b12_0>the Quran and the Sunna<b12_0/>.
